cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the key concepts in the design, manufacture, and use of efficatious dosage forms. The course covers the characteristics of different delivery routes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pharmaceutics 1

cmCourseInfo.description: Structural and mechanistic determinants of drug action at the molecular level. Topics include the physicalchemical properties of drugs per se as they relate to therapeutic intervention and the biophysical and biochemical properties of enzymes and nucleic acids that underlie and are affected by their interactions with drugs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Pharmacology 1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

cmCourseInfo.description: Structural and mechanistic determinants of drug action via macromolecules that effect cellular signalling. Neurohumoral receptors and other signalling proteins are grouped according to their structure and mechanism of action. Native properties and their modulation by drugs are discussed in the context of basic principles of molecular pharmacology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Pharmacology 2

courses.name: Establishing the Bioequivalence of Pharmaceutical Products

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to human clinical trial design for the demonstration of pharmaceutical bioequivalence of drug products. Students will learn the principles underlying the regulations and methods employed in bioequivalence studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Establishing the Bioequivalence of Pharmaceutical Products

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that the times for this course are different in Fall and Winter, as follows -- 

Fall Term: 

  • Mondays 3:00 to 4:00 p.m. (lecture)
  • Thursdays 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. in PB 860 (lab)

Winter Term: 

  • Tuesdays 11:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. (lecture)
  • Thursdays 1:00 to 5:00 p.m. in PB 860 (lab).

 

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Labs will be delivered in-person with social distancing for the Fall and Winter semester. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

courses.name: Application of Medicinal Chemistry to Pharmacology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course shows students the links between basic science and the drugs used therapeutically to treat clinical problems. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Application of Medicinal Chemistry to Pharmacology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHC301H1, PHC320H1, and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.

notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

There will be an introductory online session (either online or in-person depending on what circumstances allow), to explain the format of the course. The core of the course is made up of a series of ungraded online “quizzes” with feedback.  There will be an oral online Socratic examination.

Delivery Instructions

All lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Students will require to access the recorded lectures through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will consider many of the topics presented in the first half in much greater detail including a rigorous examination of the interpretation of experimental data. This course is intended for students whose research or interest is in the thermodynamics of biological molecules. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who are interested in the critical analysis of global health policy and the interrelationship between global and domestic policy issues. The course will introduce students generally to the basic concepts and issues in global health with a particular focus on pharmaceutical policy. We will address key issues in health and discuss core institutional and transnational actors, how governments in different jurisdictions manage public health responsibilities, the tension between economic imperatives and health objectives, global obligations, and pressure from special interest groups. More narrowly, we will analyse a breadth of complex policies questions. Examples include: the research and development global divide, policial issues influences on pharmaceutical policy, how global commitments, such as membership in the World Trade Organization, conflict with or correspond to domestic policy directions and national sovereignty. Guest speakers will lead some sessions. This course will consist of lectures, guest discuttions, case studies and student-led presentations. This is restricted to students in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Pharmaceutical Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.

The goal is to deepen the student’s understanding of the scientific basis and practical techniques relevant to modern pharmaceutical development. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission from the Course Coordinator and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Research projects will be in-person or online, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Project interviews will be performed synchronously online or in-person, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Presentation elements of research projects may be administered either synchronously online, in-person, or both depending on what circumstances allow for in the Winter term.

Delivery Instructions

Research projects will be in-person or online, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Mid-course evaluations will be performed synchronously online or in-person, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Presentation elements of research projects may be administered either synchronously online, in-person, or both depending on what circumstances allow for in the Winter term.
